DOC.HEAD: Former Houston Police Chief Dies
DOC.TEXT: Herman Short, a former Houston police chief who gained a national reputation as a law-and-order hard-liner, has died after suffering a lengthy heart ailment. He was 71. Short, who served as chief from 1964 to 1973, evoked the ire of civil rights leaders in the late 1960s for his handling of racial disturbances, but supporters said his tough stance in the face of rioting prevented Houston from faring far worse. He once was mentioned as a potential running mate for 1968 conservative presidential candidate George Wallace. Short resigned on the eve of the inauguration of former Mayor Fred Hofheinz, who planned to fire the chief the moment he took office. ``We were essentially an all-white police department under Herman that believed in heavy-handed tactics'' that included the use of illegal wiretaps, Hofheinz said Thursday. Wiretapping indictments were returned against officers who had served under Short, but he was never charged with wrongdoing. ``Certainly we made mistakes as does everyone, but I never ruled in any way except in accordance with the rules,'' Short said five years after his retirement. Short died of cardiac arrest Thursday at Methodist Hospital, where he had been listed in serious to critical condition since he was admitted Dec. 6, said hospital spokeswoman Brenda Cook. Survivors include his wife, Maxine; a son, Robert Short of Houston; and two stepdaughters, Leslie Adams of Bastrop, Texas, and Charlotte Bivins of Greenbrier, W.Va. Services are scheduled for Saturday at Niday South Park Funeral Home in Pearland, Texas.
